The War Cabinet further considered the position of illegalJewish immigrants into Palestine.The Secretary of State for the Colonies said that the volume ofthis immigration had increased since the German occupation of roumania. There was now a formidable traffic, organised as a regular trade, in ships which were often unseaworthy or on whichconditions were indescribable, The total number of jewish immigrants into Palestine over the period of five years contemplated in the White Paper was 75,000, but nearly half that number had entered in under 18 months. Most of these illegal immigrants came from Central Europe, and it was reasonable to assume that theenemy had taken steps to ensure the presence among them of anumber of enemy agents.The Secretary of State added that Dr. Weizmann, when he had seen him a. few days ago, although he had not assented to the pro-posal to send these illegal immigrants to Mauritius, had said that in substance he could not dissent from it. He had, however, takenexception to the wording of a Proclamation issued by the HighCommissioner for Palestine as to the action to be taken in regard toillegal immigrants.In discussion, some objection was seen to the terms of thisProclamation, which had stated that the illegal Jewish immigrantswho were being sent to Mauritius would not be allowed to enterPalestine or to remain in the Colony after the war. It was urgedthat the Proclamation should not have taken away from these people the right to take their chance with other applicants of obtainingentry to Palestine in a legal way.It was also suggested that the proposal to keep these illegal immigrants in an internment camp in Mauritius was perhapsunduly severe.The Secretary of State for the Colonies said that it was impos-sible to put large numbers of aliens, many of them enemy aliens, ina British Colony in wartime without making arrangements for theirdue surveillance. All possible steps were being taken to treat themin a humane way.Discussion followed as to whether the illegal immigrants whohad been saved after the S.S. Patria had sunk in Haifa harbourshould be deported to Mauritius or be allowed to remain inPalestine.The Secretary of State for the Colonies was afraid that theGovernments policy in regard to the suppression of illegal immigra-tion would be gravely weakened if these people were allowed to stay in Palestine. If this were allowed, he feared that it was only toolikely to encourage further acts of sabotage by other illegal immigrants, in order to obtain a similar concession. He would atleast like to discuss the matter with the High Commissioner, witha view to seeing whether some could be allowed to remain and the others sent to Mauritius.After further discussion, the War Cabinet agreed as follows : (1) The Proclamation which had been issued by the HighCommissioner for Palestine should stand, but a suitableexplanatory statement should be issued.(2) The illegal immigrants who had been saved from theS.S. Patria should be allowed to remain in Palestine, onthe usual conditions, subject to a careful scrutiny (inwhich the Jewish authorities might be asked to assist) tomake sure whether any enemy agents or other undesirablepersons were among them.(3) The action in (2) could be justified as a special act ofclemency, having regard to the sufferings which theseimmigrants had undergone in the S.S. Patria. (4) That the above should be the only exception made to thepolicy of the Proclamation, and that in future all otherillegal immigrants attempting to enter Palestine shouldbe diverted to Mauritius or elsewhere.(5) In the meantime, measures should be taken with a view to making the conditions of internment in Mauritius as little burdensome as possible.Richmond Terrace, S.W. 1,November 27, 1940.
